abstract.title: Purpose of review
abstract.p: Not all patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia develop acute pancreatitis. We surveyed recent literature on inter-individual genetic variation in susceptibility to pancreatitis.

sec.title: Recent findings
sec.p: Genetic determinants of pancreatitis include: rare Mendelian disorders caused by highly penetrant pathogenic variants in genes involved in trypsinogen activation; uncommon susceptibility variants in genes involved in trypsinogen activation, protein misfolding as well as calcium metabolism and cystic fibrosis, that have variable penetrance and show a range of odds ratios for pancreatitis; and common polymorphisms in many of the same genes that have only a small effect on risk. The role of these genetic variants in modulating pancreatitis risk in hypertriglyceridemia is unclear. However, among genetic determinants of plasma triglycerides, those predisposing to more severe hypertriglyceridemia associated with chylomicronemia appear to have higher pancreatitis risk.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Currently, among patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia, the most consistent predictor of pancreatitis risk is the triglyceride level. Furthermore, pancreatitis risk appears to be modulated by a higher genetic burden of factors associated with greater magnitude of triglyceride elevation. The role of common and rare genetic determinants of pancreatitis itself in this metabolic context is unclear.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Severe hypertriglyceridemia is a complex, multifactorial condition that results from interactions between genetic predisposition and numerous secondary factors [1]. The risk to health of severe hypertriglyceridemia is acute pancreatitis and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in many but not all cases [1]. Experienced clinicians have encountered patients with profound hypertriglyceridemia from chylomicronemia who avoid developing pancreatitis. Other patients develop pancreatitis at a relatively low threshold triglyceride level. The basis for inter-individual differences in expression of pancreatitis among patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia is unknown. Here we briefly review evidence that both rare and common genetic variants can explain inter-individual differences in susceptibility to pancreatitis generally and specifically in the context of hypertriglyceridemia.

sec.title: BRIEF OVERVIEW OF THE CLINICAL ISSUE
sec.p: Acute pancreatitis is hallmarked by inflammation of the pancreas, resulting in severe epigastric pain, along with elevated serum pancreatic enzymes – particularly pancreatic lipase – sometimes together with radiographic findings [2▪]. Acute pancreatitis has an annual incidence of 10 to 35 per 100 000 individuals in North America, and compared to other acute conditions it is associated with relatively longer duration of hospitalization and higher mortality [3]. Acute pancreatitis episodes may recur leading to long term complications such as chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocyst formation, pancreatic necrosis, and pancreatic failure with endocrine and exocrine insufficiency [2▪].

The pathophysiology of acute pancreatitis has been attributed to diverse mechanisms including pathological calcium signaling, mitochondrial dysfunction, endoplasmic reticulum stress, an impaired unfolded protein response and impaired autophagy [2▪]. However, the most well accepted core mechanism is autodigestion due to premature trypsinogen activation into trypsin, which is the main enzyme responsible for the activation of digestive enzymes following its secretion into the duodenum. Premature activation of digestive enzymes by trypsin within the pancreas is thought to trigger injury. The ensuing local pro-inflammatory response in turn perpetuates pancreatic tissue damage. In more severe cases, local inflammation can activate a systemic inflammatory response syndrome, which may progress to multiorgan dysfunction and occasionally shock and death [2▪].

Common etiologies of acute pancreatitis include biliary disease (mainly gallstones), heavy alcohol consumption, hypertriglyceridemia or as a complication of endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography [2▪]. Less commonly pancreatitis can result from trauma, infections, drugs, toxins, or it can be idiopathic [2▪]. In addition, genetic factors can influence the risk of pancreatitis [4▪▪,5▪,6▪,7▪▪,8▪,9▪], including pathogenic rare variants that cause hereditary forms of pancreatitis, and both rare and common genetic noncausal variants that predispose to pancreatitis either directly or as drivers of its risk factors (see Table 1). Other factors that may influence expression of pancreatitis include gene–gene interactions, epigenetic or environmental influences, and individual patient attributes [2▪,7▪▪].

sec.title: CAUSAL GENETIC VARIANTS FOR HEREDITARY PANCREATITIS
sec.p: Acute, recurrent acute and chronic pancreatitis essentially form a phenotypic continuum with overlapping pathogenic mechanisms [2▪]. Their genetic determinants also overlap somewhat [4▪▪,5▪,6▪]. The term “hereditary pancreatitis” refers to a small subset of cases that clearly show a monogenic, Mendelian pattern of inheritance in multigenerational families. Most gene variants associated with hereditary pancreatitis lead to altered activation and degradation of trypsinogen into trypsin, including gain-of-function variants and proteotoxic variants [2▪,4▪▪,7▪▪]. Also, cellular mechanisms are normally in place to guard against premature trypsin activation within the pancreas [6▪]. Pathogenic variants in the genes that encode protective factors, for example, SPINK1, can predispose to pancreatitis and underlie many cases of hereditary pancreatitis [4▪▪,7▪▪]. Because these rare Mendelian disorders are expressed early in life and affected individuals have relapsing acute pancreatitis, the phenotype can evolve into chronic pancreatitis, which is the commonest reported hereditary phenotype [6▪]. Genetic loci are often similar for acute and chronic pancreatitis. These loci were usually discovered by genetic mapping efforts in affected families or in case-control experiments.

Using the most stringent criteria for causality from the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics [10] – that is, very rare allele frequency together with phenotype–genotype co-segregation in multigenerational families plus molecular dysfunction demonstrated either experimentally or through essentially unequivocal bioinformatic modeling – only two genes can be said to have naturally occurring human pathogenic variants that cause hereditary pancreatitis [11]. These are heterozygous gain-of-function variants in PRSS1 (OMIM 276000) encoding cationic trypsinogen and heterozygous loss-of-function variants in SPINK1 (OMIM 167790) encoding pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor Kazal type 1. These gene products are categorized mechanistically under the “trypsin-dependent pathway” (Table 1).

sec.title: HEREDITARY PANCREATITIS DUE TO CAUSAL VARIANTS IN THE PRSS1 GENE
sec.p: Gain-of-function variants in PRSS1 include copy number and missense variants and also gain-of-proteotoxicity missense variants that result in increased trypsinogen activation and/or increased trypsin stability, eventually promoting trypsin-mediated autodigestion within pancreatic acinar cells. Pathogenic gain-of-function variants in PRSS1 have been implicated in ∼80% of cases of autosomal dominant hereditary pancreatitis [7▪▪]. However, fewer than two dozen families with pathogenic PRSS1 variants have been reported. The most recurring variant is PRSS1 p.Arg122His, which has 93% penetrance for pancreatitis and shows typical autosomal dominant inheritance. Penetrance of pancreatitis in carriers of some other PRSS1 variants is variable and is influenced by secondary factors.

The functional consequence of pathogenic gain-of-function variants in PRSS1 is to either prevent chymotrypsin C (CTRC)-mediated trypsinogen degradation, increase trypsinogen autoactivation, or cause trypsinogen misfolding that results in reduced secretion, intracellular retention and elevated endoplasmic reticulum stress markers [7▪▪]. PRSS1 variants in children predict aggressive disease with earlier onset and rapid progression to chronic pancreatitis, with a more severe disease phenotype associated with p.Arg122His and p.Asn29Ile variants [12]. But because highly penetrant pathogenic PRSS1 gain-of-function variants are rare, they are not major contributors to inter-individual variation in pancreatitis susceptibility either in the general population or in those with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

sec.title: HEREDITARY PANCREATITIS DUE TO CAUSAL VARIANTS IN THE SPINK1 GENE
sec.p: The gene product of SPINK1 is expressed in pancreatic acinar cells during an inflammatory reaction and acts to inhibit prematurely activated intrapancreatic trypsin [13]. Loss-of-function variants in SPINK1 can undermine this protective effect, resulting in increased trypsin-mediated digestion within acinar cells. However, in the absence of the background of pancreatic inflammation, pathogenic variants in SPINK1 appear to have minimal impact on pancreatitis risk. The most frequently reported rare pathogenic variants are SPINK p.Asn34Ser in Europeans and c.194+2T>C in Korean and Han Chinese patients, respectively [14,15]. Interestingly, the SPINK p.Asn34Ser variant was recently shown to be a surrogate marker linked genetically with a dysfunctional noncoding regulatory variant ∼4 kb upstream of the SPINK1 gene [16]. Inheritance patterns have been described as both autosomal recessive in families with a history of familial pancreatitis carrying two mutations and autosomal dominant in individuals with chronic pancreatitis and a single-copy heterozygous SPINK1 mutation. Given these various caveats, rare SPINK1 loss-of-function variants are unlikely to be major contributors to pancreatitis susceptibility either in the general population or in those with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

sec.title: RARE GENETIC VARIANTS THAT PREDISPOSE TO PANCREATITIS
sec.p: Masson et al.[11] recently suggested using the term “familial pancreatitis” for clinical presentations in which association with either rare or common genetic variants is shown statistically in unrelated people, but for which there is minimal evidence of transgenerational inheritance. This more liberal phenotypic definition compared to “hereditary pancreatitis” expands the range of genetic loci and variant types that are determinants of pancreatitis. Since such variants are cumulatively more prevalent, they also include a larger segment of the population. Although variants of this type are not definitively or absolutely associated with disease expression, they are statistically associated, which might nonetheless be useful for predicting pancreatitis risk. Finally, such genetic variants might explain some inter-individual differences in hypertriglyceridemia-associated pancreatitis risk.

sec.title: TRYPSIN-DEPENDENT PATHWAY SUSCEPTIBILITY VARIANTS IN THE PRSS1, PRSS2 AND SPINK1 GENES
sec.p: The ultrarare pathogenic PRSS1 and SPINK1 Mendelian variants described above fit within the “trypsin-dependent pathway” mechanistic subgroup [7▪▪,11]. But, this subgroup also includes many more rare variants in these two genes that predispose to rather than directly cause pancreatitis. Most of the >50 pancreatitis-associated variants in PRSS1 show modest or weak effects - consistent with lower penetrance - compared with the strong effect pathogenic variants in hereditary pancreatitis families. For instance, the well known infrequent PRSS1 p.Arg122His and p.Gly208Ala variants have odds ratios for pancreatitis ranging from 4 to 10 [11], consistent with predisposition but not causation.

Adjacent to PRSS1 on chromosome 7q34 is PRSS2 (OMIM 601564) encoding anionic trypsinogen. No highly penetrant causal variants have been reported in this gene, although the PRSS2 p.Gly191Arg variant has a 5% population frequency and reduces pancreatitis risk by ∼3−6-fold, possibly because the variant protein is prone to autocatalysis and inactivation [7▪▪]. The overall absence of pathogenic PRSS2 Mendelian variants is notable, although reasons for this are unclear [7▪▪].

On the other hand, >30 rare disease-associated variants have been reported in SPINK1, most of which are incompletely penetrant and show a wide range of odds ratios for pancreatitis [13]. As with most PRSS1 variants, most SPINK1 variants alone are not sufficient for developing pancreatitis, since their prevalence is ∼1−2% in the general healthy population [12]. Here, the development of pancreatitis likely requires additional environmental, patient or genetic factors. But while they do not deliver a 100% chance of developing pancreatitis, the odds ratios are relatively large compared to variants in other complex diseases. Future research will determine whether measuring these predisposing effects is clinically useful.

sec.title: TRYPSIN-DEPENDENT PATHWAY PREDISPOSING VARIANTS IN THE CTRC GENE
sec.p: Another gene whose product acts within the trypsin-dependent pathway and which harbors predisposing rare variants for pancreatitis is CTRC (OMIM 601405) encoding chymotrypsin C. CTRC specifically degrades trypsinogen/trypsin, and loss-of-function variants enhance autodigestion [7▪▪]. No families with co-segregation of CTRC variants and pancreatitis phenotypes have been reported. However, statistical associations of these variants with pancreatitis in the unrelated general population have been replicated. For instance, the CTRC p.Arg254Trp variant has an odds ratio for pancreatitis of ∼2−3, whereas a bundle of rare CTRC loss-of-function variants has an odds ratio for pancreatitis of ∼4 [7▪▪]. Compared with genetic factors in other complex diseases, the odds ratios for such CTRC variants in pancreatitis are relatively large. This might be useful clinically, especially if combined with other genetic markers to increase discriminatory and predictive power.

sec.title: MISFOLDING-DEPENDENT PATHWAY OF GENETIC RISK OF PANCREATITIS
sec.p: Other trypsin-dependent genes have rare predisposing variants that act through a distinct pathogenic mechanism referred to as the “misfolding-dependent pathway” [7▪▪]. This pathogenic mechanism is characterized by decreased secretion of the misfolded mutant protein, resulting in intracellular accumulation and increased endoplasmic reticulum stress leading ultimately to acinar cell damage. As mentioned above, a few pathogenic variants in PRSS1 in hereditary pancreatitis families are referred to as proteotoxic because of misfolding. Other proteotoxic PRSS1 misfolding variants that have been found in sporadic cases of pancreatitis include p.Cys139Phe, p.Cys139Ser and p.Leu104Phe [7▪▪].

Another gene locus with pancreatitis predisposing variants that act via a protein misfolding trypsin-independent mechanism is CPA1 (OMIM 114850) encoding carboxypeptidase A1 [7▪▪]. Certain rare CPA1 variants cause misfolding with intracellular accumulation of protein and increased endoplasmic reticulum stress and were associated with odds ratios of >25 for chronic and early onset sporadic pancreatitis [17]. A few CPA1 variants appeared to show familial inheritance [18,19]. However, enthusiasm for this gene has been curbed by observations suggesting that most apparently pathogenic CPA1 variants are not associated with pancreatitis [20]. More work is required to establish the importance of CPA1 in predisposition to pancreatitis.

Similar unreplicated associations exist between for pathogenic variants in CEL (OMIM 114840) encoding carboxyl ester lipase, which interestingly is also the causal gene for maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 8 (MODY8) [7▪▪]. One particular pancreatitis-associated large-scale variant called CEL-HYB1 is an abnormal hybrid allele resulting from a recombination event between CEL and its neighboring pseudogene CELP; its population frequency is 1–2% [21]. The abnormal gene product is prone to misfolding [22] and the risk of chronic pancreatitis associated with CEL-HYB1 was increased by five-fold [21]. In contrast, a second CEL-HYB allele with a premature stop codon in exon 10 described in a study of three Asian populations was found to not be associated with chronic pancreatitis [23]. As with most susceptibility loci, more work is required to definitively establish the role of CEL in pancreatitis risk.

sec.title: PREDISPOSING VARIANTS FOR PANCREATITIS IN THE CFTR GENE
sec.p: Pathogenic variants in CFTR (OMIM 602421) encoding the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator, with or without concurrent manifestations of classical cystic fibrosis, can confer increased risk for pancreatitis and pancreatic damage as a result of failure to clear pancreatic ducts from elevated mucus levels, with progression to fibrosis and cysts [24]. Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the presence of two severe CFTR loss-of-function variants [24]. Some severe CFTR mutations can lead to early-onset pancreatic insufficiency, often in infancy or childhood [24]. Patients with both a severe and mild CFTR pathogenic variant are more likely to present with episodes of acute pancreatitis [25]. Heterozygous carriers of either CFTR p.Phe508del or p.Arg117His have also been found to be enriched among chronic pancreatitis patients, with reported odds ratios of ∼2–3 [8▪]. Because they are relatively common across geographic ancestries, screening for heterozygous CFTR variants in hypertriglyceridemia-associated pancreatitis may be worthwhile.

sec.title: COMMON VARIANTS FOR PANCREATITIS FROM GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDIES
sec.p: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) utilizing common, mostly nonfunctional single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) positioned strategically and densely across the genome are a standard tool for finding genetic determinants of complex traits [26]. One benefit of GWAS is identification of multiple disease-associated SNP genotypes that can be combined into a polygenic score, which is a proven metric to test scientific and clinical hypotheses [26]. Interestingly, typical case–control GWAS for pancreatitis are relatively scarce and no polygenic score appears to have yet been reported for pancreatitis, despite numerous publications of polygenic scores for other pancreatic disorders, such as pancreatic cancer. Nonetheless, significant GWAS findings for pancreatitis are worth discussing in detail.

In 2018, Rosendahl et al.[27] reported a GWAS in 1959 and 1659 mainly European patients with alcoholic and nonalcoholic chronic pancreatitis, respectively, and >11 000 total control subjects. They identified and replicated several highly significant pancreatitis-associated SNP loci, including signals at the well known loci CTRC, PRSS1, PRSS2 and SPINK1[27]. Furthermore, they found two additional significant pancreatitis-associated GWAS signals, that is, SNPs at the CLDN2-MORC4 gene locus and a common complex genetic variant designated as the CTRB1-CTRB2 inversion [27].

In 2022, Schmidt et al.[28▪] reported a GWAS in 584 mainly European patients with nonalcoholic chronic pancreatitis and 6040 controls coupled with analysis of RNA transcripts in alcohol-exposed pancreatic tissue. They found that common variants at CTRC and SPINK1 reached genome-wide significance in nonalcoholic chronic pancreatitis, while CTRC and CLDN2-MORC4 risk variants colocalized with altered mRNA expression in pancreatic tissue [28▪]. The concordance of findings between the independent GWAS of Rosendahl et al.[27] and Schmidt et al.[28▪] was notable, since the top loci in both studies were identical to known loci described above, that is, CTRC, SPINK1 and PRSS1. In addition, the novel strong signals for CLDN2-MORC4 and the CTRB1-CTRB2 inversion deserve further comment.

CLDN2 encodes claudin-2 (OMIM 300520) which is expressed in multiple tissues and is probably important in maintaining tight junctions between cells. Previously, rare CLDN2 pathogenic variants were associated with chronic pancreatitis [29], and common SNPs at the CLDN2-MORC4 locus, namely rs7057398 and rs12688220 were associated with chronic pancreatitis risk in subjects of East Asian and South Asian ancestry [30]. The replication in independent samples indicates that genetic variation at this locus should continue to be studied, especially in the context of polygenic risk of pancreatitis.

The 16.6 kb inversion of the CTRB1 (OMIM 118890)/CTRB2 (OMIM 619620) locus on chromosome 16q23, encoding chymotrypsin B1 and chymotrypsin B2, respectively, is the major – that is, more common – allele in both European and Chinese populations, with frequencies of ∼0.8 and ∼1.0, respectively [31]. The essentially monomorphic allele frequency indicates that it cannot be an important determinant of pancreatitis risk in Chinese people. Furthermore, DNA sequencing of the CTRB1–CTRB2 locus did not reveal an association between rare variants with either alcoholic or nonalcoholic chronic pancreatitis [32]. Given these discrepancies, the potential scientific and clinical utility of variants at CTRB1/CTRB2 in predisposition to pancreatitis is unclear.

sec.title: MISCELLANEOUS GENETIC VARIANTS STUDIED FOR ASSOCIATION WITH PANCREATITIS
sec.p: Numerous small case-control and cohort candidate gene association studies have reported pancreatitis-associated variants at gene loci such as FUT2 (OMIM 182100) encoding fucosyltransferase 2 [33], UBR1 (OMIM 605981) encoding ubiquitin ligase E3 alpha [34,35], GGT1 (OMIM 612346) encoding gamma-glutamyltransferase [36], PNLIP (OMIM 246600) encoding pancreatic lipase [37] and CELA3B (OMIM 618694) encoding chymotrypsin-like elastase 3B [38]. Recently, for CELA3B, rare pathogenic variants have been reported in patients with pancreatitis, supporting the idea that this could be a valid candidate gene [39]. However, for the other genes, the findings have generally not been replicated in larger-scale GWAS nor supported by mechanistic data, and we feel they probably should not merit further consideration until such evidence is available.

Because of the role of proinflammatory cytokines in progression to severe pancreatitis, variants in selected candidate genes for these pathways have also been studied for association with pancreatitis. A comprehensive meta-analysis by Van den Berg et al.[40▪▪] found that most studies were negative, with some borderline evidence in favor of associations with acute pancreatitis for variants at IL1B and IL6 genes, encoding interleukins 1B and 6, respectively. However, neither locus has been prominent in GWAS of pancreatitis [27,28▪]. Similarly, findings for common variants in candidate genes involved in oxidative stress and apoptosis, such as several encoding members of the glutathione S-transferase, caspase, tumor necrosis factor and tumor associated protein gene families were negative [41], and need not be considered further unless new data emerge.

sec.title: GENETIC DETERMINANTS OF PANCREATITIS RISK FACTORS: RESULTS FROM MENDELIAN RANDOMIZATION
sec.p: Yuan et al.[42▪▪] in 2021 reported a study of >360 000 individuals from the UK BioBank and >12 200 individuals from the FinnGen consortium. They constructed genetic instruments to serve as surrogate variables for lifelong exposure to known pancreatitis risk factors including gallstone disease, cigarette smoking, diabetes, serum calcium levels, serum triglycerides, and alcohol consumption. They constructed their genetic instruments for: gallstones using 32 previously reported GWAS SNPs from an Icelandic population [43]; smoking initiation using 378 SNPs from GWAS in >1.2 million individuals [44]; diabetes using 558 SNPs from GWAS in >1.4 million individuals [45]; serum calcium using 7 SNPs from GWAS in >60 000 Europeans [46]; triglycerides using 440 previously reported SNPs from GWAS in >400 000 Europeans [47]; and alcohol consumption using 99 SNPs from GWAS in >900 000 Europeans [44]. For acute pancreatitis, significant odds ratios were 1.74, 1.15, 1.56 and 1.14 for gallstone disease, triglycerides, smoking and diabetes, respectively [42▪▪]. For chronic pancreatitis, significant odds ratios were 1.27, 1.47 and 1.86 for gallstone disease, triglycerides and smoking, respectively [42▪▪]. Because Mendelian randomization studies claim to identify causal relationships, the results from Yuan et al.[42▪▪] support the idea that common genetic determinants for gallstone disease, diabetes, smoking and triglycerides are directly causal for pancreatitis itself. However, caveats in the design and interpretation of Mendelian randomization studies mean that results are not automatically infallible [48]. It would be important to replicate these findings using an analogous study design in other cohorts and populations.

sec.title: GENETIC DETERMINANTS OF PANCREATITIS IN THE CONTEXT OF HYPERCALCEMIA
sec.p: Hypercalcemia is a risk state for pancreatitis although it is less common than gallstones, alcohol use or even hypertriglyceridemia. Primary hyperparathyroidism with hypercalcemia has been found in <0.5% of cases of pancreatitis [49], and about 90% of patients with hypercalcemia have either primary hyperparathyroidism or a malignancy [50]. General consideration of genetic etiologies for hypercalcemia is beyond the scope of this review; for instance, some cases of hyperparathyroidism are part of multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes, which have a distinctive clinical presentation and genetic basis [51]. However, certain genes in calcium metabolism, including CASR (OMIM 601199) encoding the calcium sensing receptor and TRPV6 (OMIM 606680) encoding transporter receptor potential cation channel subfamily V member 6 (also the gene for transient neonatal hyperparathyroidism) are predisposition loci for pancreatitis and will thus be discussed here briefly.

The CASR gene product is a G-protein-coupled receptor that is expressed in human pancreatic acinar and ductal cells as well as nonexocrine cells, and is the causal gene for hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, type I [52]. CASR variants were reported to play a role in SPINK1-related chronic pancreatitis [52] and an alcohol-dependent association between chronic pancreatitis and the CASR p.Arg990Gly variant was reported in a US population [53]. However, other studies have found no associations between common CASR gene variants and pancreatitis [54].

The TRPV6 gene encodes a calcium selective ion channel that is predominantly expressed in pancreatic ducts. Functionally defective TRPV6 variants were observed in a cohort of Japanese patients [55] and replicated in European patient cohorts [56,57]. TRPV6 expression was decreased with these variants, supporting a mechanistic role of the cation channels in pancreatitis risk.

sec.title: GENETIC PREDISPOSITION TO SEVERE HYPERTRIGLYCERIDEMIA AND PANCREATITIS RISK
sec.p: Hypertriglyceridemia is seen in up to 10% of all acute pancreatitis episodes [4▪▪]. Hypertriglyceridemia is both a risk factor and factor that modulates the severity of clinical presentation of pancreatitis [58]. Mislocalization of pancreatic lipase in the plasma compartment is considered to be important in pathogenesis, although several mechanisms have been proposed [59▪]. The threshold plasma triglyceride level that triggers an episode of acute pancreatitis is variable, but to a first approximation pancreatitis risk is proportional to triglyceride levels [60]. This gradient of risk is seen even at mild-to-moderate levels of triglycerides [61]. However, this could simply reflect the fact that mild-to-moderate hypertriglyceridemia is a risk marker for future onset of severe hypertriglyceridemia rather than being directly causal for pancreatitis.

Severe hypertriglyceridemia is sometimes defined as fasting triglycerides >10 mmol/l (>885 mg/dl) [62], a level seen in about 1 in 400 adults in North America [63]. Triglyceride levels this high indicate the pathological presence of fasting chylomicrons and are threshold for high risk of pancreatitis [64]. This risk increases sharply with triglycerides > 20 mmol/l (>1770 mg/dl) [64]; above this level the risk of pancreatitis is 4% over 1 year and 6% over 2 years [63].

Chylomicronemia syndrome implies one or more characteristic clinical features that include failure to thrive, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, lipemia retinalis, eruptive xanthomas, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, diarrhea, seizures, and encephalopathy [62]. The two main chylomicronemia syndromes are familial chylomicronemia syndrome and multifactorial chylomicronemia syndrome [62]. Familial chylomicronemia syndrome is a Mendelian recessive condition caused by biallelic rare pathogenic loss-of-function variants in lipolysis-related genes, namely LPL (OMIM 609708) encoding lipoprotein lipase and accounts for 60–80% of cases, APOC2 (OMIM 608083) encoding apolipoprotein (apo) C-II; APOA5 (OMIM 606368) encoding apo A-V, GPIHBP1 (OMIM 612757) encoding glycosylphosphatidylinositol HDL binding protein 1, and LMF1 (OMIM 611761) encoding lipase maturation factor 1 [62,65]. In contrast, multifactorial chylomicronemia syndrome is a non-Mendelian complex genetic disorder associated with either: heterozygosity for a pathogenic variant in one of the above five genes, seen in 15–20% of affected subjects [65]; or polygenic predisposition due to aggregated weak effect SNP loci in up to 50% of affected individuals [62,65].

The lifetime relative risk of pancreatitis is 70–80% in familial chylomicronemia syndrome compared to 20–30% in multifactorial chylomicronemia syndrome [66]. This likely reflects a lifetime of sustained refractory extreme severity of chylomicronemia in the former condition [66]. There is other evidence that increased genetic burden for hypertriglyceridemia is associated with pancreatitis.

For instance, Deshotels et al.[67] recently reported a study in 363 lipid clinic patients of whom 176, 129 and 58 had triglyceride levels <2.3 mmol/l (<200 mg/dl), 2.3–11.1 mmol/l (200–999 mg/dl) and >11.1 mmol/l (>1000 mg/dl), respectively. Patients were genotyped for rare pathogenic variants in LPL, APOC2, APOA5, GPIHBP1 and LMF1 as well as for a polygenic score for high triglyceride levels. The authors found that three and 34 patients had familial and multifactorial chylomicronemia syndrome, respectively. Also, 59 patients had a high pathogenic score for triglycerides whereas 20 patients had both a heterozygous pathogenic variant and a high polygenic score. The main findings were confined to pancreatitis risk in patients with the most severe triglyceride elevation. Specifically, of 37 individuals with a history of acute pancreatitis, 35 were in the subgroup with triglyceride >11.1 mmol/l. Compared with those who had neither a pathogenic variant nor a high polygenic score, the authors observed that those with either a pathogenic variant or a high polygenic risk score had no increased risk of acute pancreatitis, but those with both a pathogenic variant and a high polygenic risk score had higher triglycerides and five-fold increased risk of pancreatitis compared to all others [67]. The authors concluded that hypertriglyceridemic patients with both a heterozygous rare pathogenic variant and a high polygenic score had extremely high pancreatitis risk and were candidates for closer medical attention [67]. In contrast, in a study of two cohorts of lipid clinic patients with fasting triglyceride >10 mmol/l, we found no increased risk of pancreatitis in those with both a heterozygous rare pathogenic variant plus high polygenic score, compared with either genetic factor alone [68]. Studies in prospective epidemiologic cohorts could help define additivity of genetic factors.

Severe HTG has also been observed in individuals with familial partial lipodystrophy (FLPD) subtype 2 caused by pathogenic rare variants in LMNA (OMIM 150330) encoding nuclear lamin A/C [69]. In these patients, hypertriglyceridemia severity is typically mild-to-moderate. However, about 15% of patients experience sustained severe hypertriglyceridemia >10 mmol/l and this subgroup has a very high lifetime risk of acute pancreatitis, emphasizing again that irrespective of the genetic background, the proximal determinant of pancreatitis risk is the severity of the triglyceride elevation [69].

sec.title: GENETIC DETERMINANTS OF PANCREATITIS RISK IN PATIENTS WITH HYPERTRIGLYCERIDEMIA
sec.p: We could find no reports in which genetic determinants of pancreatitis were studied in patients with hypertriglyceridemia. However, an analogous study in patients with alcohol use provides a possible framework. Specifically, Rosendahl et al.[27] reported that the top five significant gene loci in European patients with alcohol-associated chronic pancreatitis (significant odds ratios shown) were: SPINK1 3.82, CLND2-MORC4 2.57, PRSS1-PRSS2 1.84; CTRC 1.83; and CTRB1-CRTB2 1.35. It would be important to determine whether these loci similarly provide association signals in a GWAS performed in patients with hypertriglyceridemia.

sec.title: SUMMARY AND INTERPRETATION
sec.p: There is a complex interaction between genetic, environmental, patient-specific and other risk factors underlying pancreatitis risk (see Fig. 1). Most cases of unexplained pancreatitis are not fully accounted for by genetic determinants. Exceptions include high penetrance variants in PRSS1 and SPINK1. Expression may also be influenced by gene–gene and gene–environment interactions. Additionally, risk states for pancreatitis such as gallstones have their own genetic determinants.

caption.p: Overview of genetic determinants of pancreatitis in the context of hypertriglyceridemia. Three general categories of genetic determinants are shown. Genetic determinants of hypertriglyceridemia include: biallelic pathogenic rare variants in the indicated genes causing familial chylomicronemia syndrome; heterozygous or single copy of these pathogenic variants, which are incompletely penetrant and predispose to rather than cause hypertriglyceridemia; and common single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), which act additively to increase predisposition to hypertriglyceridemia but are not causative. Genetic determinants of pancreatitis itself include: pathogenic rare variants in the indicated genes causing hereditary pancreatitis; heterozygous or single copy of these pathogenic variants, which are incompletely penetrant and predispose to rather than cause pancreatitis; and common SNPs that predisposition to pancreatitis but are not causative. We could not find polygenic risk scores for pancreatitis comprised of such SNPs. Genetic determinants of pancreatitis risk factors or precipitating factors other than hypertriglyceridemia include polygenic risk comprised of small effect SNPs that increase susceptibility to gallstones, hypercalcemia, and diabetes as well as alcohol use and smoking.

sec.p: For a patient with severe hypertriglyceridemia, do genetic factors predict risk of pancreatitis? First, biallelic pathogenic variants underlying Mendelian familial chylomicronemia syndrome are associated with greater lifetime risk of pancreatitis compared with other genotypes associated with complex multifactorial chylomicronemia syndrome. Second, among those with multifactorial chylomicronemia, the combination of both high polygenic risk from common triglyceride-associated variants plus a single copy of a pathogenic triglyceride-associated variant is much higher than among individuals with only one or none of these genetic determinants. Third, while it is tempting to speculate that inter-individual variation in pancreatitis risk in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia is modulated by pancreatitis-associated gene loci, there is no evidence for this at present. Fourth, the most reliable clinical marker of pancreatitis risk currently is the degree of triglyceride elevation rather than the patient's genotype. Definitive answers await direct proof of genetic modulators of pancreatitis risk among patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The value of a genetic diagnosis for evaluating pancreatitis risk in hypertriglyceridemia is currently unclear. However, theoretical benefits to genotyping include: providing patients with the certainty of a diagnosis; allowing for targeted familial screening; more accurate clinical prognostication and engagement of genetic counselors for family planning; tailored monitoring for any associated manifestations; and a greater understanding of the underlying pathophysiology that may eventually lead better treatments. An understanding of genetic risk may also influence eligibility and timing of interventions. At a minimum, individuals identified to carry high genetic risk should be counseled regarding avoidance of other pancreatitis triggers, such as smoking or alcohol. Furthermore, proactive dietary modification may be helpful, especially in those with familial chylomicronemia syndrome, who might also benefit from new pharmacologic treatments [70].
